site.name: Yihui He
site.description: Yihui He, AI research scientist / full stack engineer

title: Web architecture involves multiple components like a
database, message queue, cache, user interface
i
, etc., all running in conjunction to form an online service.
In the introduction of this course, I talked about why knowledge of web architecture is important to software engineers. Now we will explore it further.

This is a typical web application used in most of the applications running online. If you understand the components involved in this diagram, you can build upon this architecture to fulfill complex requirements.
I’ll go through every component step by step, starting with the
client-server
i
architecture.
A
thin client
i
is a
client
i
that holds just the
user interface
i
of the application. It contains no
business logic
i
of any sort. For every action, the
client
i
sends a request to the backend server, just like in a
three-tier
i
application.
On the contrary, the
thick client
i
holds all or some part of the
business logic
i
. These are the
two-tier
i
applications. We’ve already been through them.
The typical examples of
fat clients
i
are utility apps, online games, and so on.
REST
i
stands for
Representational State Transfer
i
. It’s a software architectural style for implementing
web services
i
Web services
i
implemented using the
REST
i
architectural style are known as the
RESTful web services
i
A
REST API
i
is an
API
i
implementation that adheres to the
REST
i
architectural constraints. It acts as an interface. The communication between the
client
i
and the server happens over
HTTP
i
. A
REST API
i
takes advantage of the
HTTP
i
methodologies to establish communication between the
client
i
and the
server
i
REST
i
also enables
servers
i
to
cache
i
the response that improves the application’s performance.
The communication between the client and the server is a stateless process. By that, I mean every communication between the client and the server is like a new one.

There is no information or memory carried over from the previous communications. So, every time a client interacts with the backend, the client has to send the authentication information to it as well. This enables the backend to figure out whether the client is authorized to access the data or not.
When implementing a
REST API
i
, the client communicates with the backend endpoints. This entirely decouples the backend and the client code.
Let’s break it down what this means.
An
API/REST/Backend
i
endpoint means the
URL
i
of the service that the client could hit. For instance,
https://myservice.com/users/{username}
c
is a backend endpoint for fetching the user details of a particular user from the service.
The
REST-based
i
service will expose this
URL
i
to all its clients to fetch the user details using the above stated
URL
i
Decoupling clients and the backend service
b
With the availability of the endpoints, the backend service does not have to worry about the client implementation. It just calls out to its multiple clients and says, “
Hey Folks! Here is the URL address of the resource/information you need. Hit it when you need it. Any client with the required authorization to access a resource can access it
i
With the
REST
i
implementation, developers can have different implementations for different clients, leveraging different technologies with separate codebases. Different clients accessing a common
REST API
i
could be a mobile browser, a desktop browser, a tablet or an
API
i
testing tool. Introducing new types of clients or modifying the client code does not affect the functionality of the backend service.
This means the clients and the backend service are decoupled.
Application development before the REST API
b
Before the
REST-based API
i
interfaces became mainstream in the industry, we often tightly coupled the backend code with the client.
Java Server Pages
i
(JSP) is one example of this.
We would always put
business logic
i
in the
JSP
i
tags. This made code refactoring and adding new features difficult because the business logic spread across different layers.

Also, on the backend, we had to write separate code/classes for handling requests from different types of clients. We needed a separate servlet for handling requests from a mobile client and a separate one for a web-based client.
After
REST APIs
i

implementation backend developers didn’t need to worry about the type of the client. All the devs had to do was provide the service endpoints to the clients and they would receive the response in a standard data transport format like
JSON
i
. It was now the responsibility of the clients to parse and render the response data.
This cut down a lot of unnecessary work for the backend developers. Also, adding new clients became a lot easier. Now, with
REST
i
, we can introduce any number of new clients without having to worry about the backend implementation.
In today’s application development landscape, there is hardly any online service implemented without a
REST API
i
. Want to access the public data of any social network? Just use their
REST API
i
Real world example of using a REST API
b
Let’s say we want to write an application to keep track of the birthdays of all our
Facebook
i
friends. The app would then send us a reminder a couple of days before the birthday of a certain friend.
To implement this, the first step would be to get the data of the birthdays of all our
Facebook
i
friends. We would write a
client
i
to hit the
Facebook Social Graph API
i
, which is a
REST-API
i
, to get the data and then run our business logic on the data.
Implementing a
REST-based API
i
has several upsides. Let’s delve into it in detail in the next lesson to have a deeper understanding.
The
REST-API
i
acts as a gateway or a single-entry point into the system. It encapsulates the
business logic
i
and handles all the
client
i
requests, taking care of the authorization, authentication, sanitizing the input data, and other necessary tasks before providing access to the application resources.
So, now we are aware of the
client-server
i
architecture. We also know what a
REST API
i
is. It acts as the interface, and the communication between the client and the server happens over
HTTP
i
Now, let’s look into the
HTTP Pull
i
and
Push-based
i
communication mechanism in the lesson up next.
There are two ways of pulling/fetching data from the server.
The first is sending an
HTTP GET
i
request to the server manually by triggering an event on the user interface by clicking a button or interacting with any other element on the web page.
The other is pulling data dynamically at regular intervals using
AJAX
i
without any human intervention.
AJAX stands for Asynchronous JavaScript and XML. The name says it all. AJAX is used for adding asynchronous behavior to the web page.
As you can see in the illustration above, instead of requesting the data manually every time with the click of a button,
AJAX
i
enables us to fetch the updated data from the server by automatically sending the requests over and over at stipulated intervals.
Upon receiving the updates, a particular section of the web page is updated dynamically by the
callback
i
method. We see this behavior all the time on
news
i
and
sports
i
websites, where the updated event information is dynamically displayed on the page without needing to reload it.
AJAX
i
uses an
XMLHttpRequest
i
object to send the requests to the server. This object is built in the browser and uses
JavaScript
i
to update the
HTML DOM
i
(Document Object Model).
AJAX
i
is commonly used with the
jQuery
i
framework to implement the asynchronous behavior on the
UI
i
This dynamic technique of requesting information from the server at regular intervals is known as
polling
i

It is important to note here that AJAX polling and AJAX Long polling are different techniques. Do not confuse them as one.AJAX polling is the HTTP Pull mechanism and AJAX Long polling is a hybrid between the HTTP Push and the Pull, based on the BAYEUX protocol. I’ve discussed it in the HTTP Push-based technologies lesson.
In the regular
client-server
i
communication, which is
HTTP PULL
i
, there is a
Time to Live
i
(TTL) for every request. It could be
30 secs
i
to
60 secs
i
, varying from browser to browser.
If the client doesn’t receive a response from the server within the
TTL
i
, the browser kills the connection and the client has to re-send the request hoping it receives the data from the server before the
TTL
i
ends again.
Open connections
i

consume resources, and there is a limit to the number of open connections a server can handle at one point. If the connections don’t close and new ones are introduced regularly over time, the server will run out of memory. Hence, the
TTL
i
is used in client-server communication.
But what if we are certain that the response will take more time than the
TTL
i
set by the browser?
In this case, we need a
persistent connection
i
between the client and the server.
A persistent connection is a network connection between the client and the server that remains open for future requests and responses, as opposed to being closed after a single communication.
This facilitates
HTTP PUSH-based
i
communication between the client and the server.
Now you might wonder how a persistent connection is possible if the browser kills the open connections to the server every
x
i
seconds?
The connection between the client and the server stays open with the help of
Heartbeat Interceptors
i
These are just blank request responses between the client and the server to prevent the browser from killing the connection.
Yes, it is.
Persistent connections
i
consume a lot of resources compared to the
HTTP PULL
i
behavior. However, there are use cases where establishing a
persistent connection
i
is vital to an application’s feature.
For instance, a browser-based multiplayer game has a pretty large amount of request-response activity within a limited time than a regular web application.
It would be apt to establish a
persistent connection
i
between the client and the server in this use case from a user experience standpoint.
Long opened connections can be implemented by multiple techniques such as
AJAX Long Polling, Web Sockets, Server-Sent Events,
i
etc.
Let’s take a look into each of these methods in the lesson up next.
A
Web Socket
i
connection is preferred when we need a persistent bi-directional low latency data flow from the client to the server and back.
Typical use-cases of
web sockets
i
are messaging, chat applications, real-time social streams, browser-based massive multiplayer games, etc. These are apps with quite a significant number of read writes compared to a regular web app.
With
web sockets
i
, we can keep the client-server connection open as long as we want.
Have bi-directional data? Go ahead with web sockets. One more thing,
web sockets
i
don’t work over
HTTP
i
. The mechanism runs over
TCP
i
. Also, the server and the client should both support
web sockets
i
. Else it won’t work.
The
WebSocket API
i
a
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebSockets_API
and
Introducing WebSockets – Bringing Sockets to the Web
i
a
https://www.html5rocks.com/en/tutorials/websockets/basics/
are good resources for further reading on
web sockets
i
Long polling
i
lies somewhere between
AJAX
i
and
Web Sockets
i
. In this technique, instead of immediately returning the empty response, the server holds the response until it finds an update to be sent to the client.

The connection in long polling stays open a bit longer compared to polling. The server doesn’t return an empty response. If the connection breaks, the client has to re-establish the connection to the server.
The upside of using this technique is that there are fewer requests sent from the client to the server than the regular polling mechanism. This cuts down a lot of network bandwidth consumption.
Long polling
i
can be used in simple asynchronous data fetch use cases when you do not want to poll the server every now and then.
HTML5 Event-Source API and Server-Sent Events
b
The
Server-Sent Events
i

(SSE) implementation takes a different approach. Instead of the client polling for data, the server automatically pushes the data to the client whenever the updates are available. The incoming messages from the server are treated as
events
i
Via this approach, the servers can initiate data transmission towards the client once the client has established the connection with an initial request.
This helps eliminate a considerable number of blank
request-response
i
cycles cutting down the bandwidth consumption by notches.
To implement the server-sent events, the backend language should support the technology. On the
UI
i
HTML5 Event-Source API
i
is used to receive the incoming data from the backend.
An important thing to note here is that once the client establishes a connection with the server, the data flow is in one direction only, from the server to the client.
SSE
i
is ideal for scenarios like a real-time Twitter feed, displaying stock quotes on the UI, real-time notifications, etc.
Streaming over HTTP
i
is ideal for cases where we need to stream extensive data over
HTTP
i
by breaking it into smaller chunks. This is made possible with
HTML5
i
and a
JavaScript Stream API
i
Both the client and the server must agree to conform to the streaming settings to stream data. This helps them determine when the stream begins and ends over an
HTTP
i
request-response model.

The technique is primarily used for streaming multimedia content, like large images, videos, etc., over HTTP. Empowered by this technique, we can watch a partially downloaded video as it downloads by playing the downloaded chunks on the client.
For further reading on Stream API,
this is a good resource
a
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Streams_API/Concepts
So, now we understand what
HTTP Pull
i
and
Push
i
are. We went through different technologies that help us establish a persistent connection between the client and the server.
Every tech has a specific use case, and
AJAX
i
is used to dynamically update the web page by polling the server at regular intervals.
Long polling
i
has a connection open time slightly longer than the polling mechanism.
Web Sockets
i
have bi-directional data flow, whereas server-sent events facilitate data flow from the server to the client.
Streaming over HTTP
i
facilitates the streaming of large objects like multimedia files.
What tech would fit best for our use case depends on the application we intend to build.
In the next lesson, let’s gain an insight into the pros and cons of the client and the server-side rendering.
Client-side rendering - How does a browser render a web page?
b
When a browser receives a web page from the server in response, it has to render the response on the window in the form of an
HTML
i
page.
To pull this off, the browser has several components, such as:
I won’t go into much detail; the gist is the browser has to do a lot of work to convert the response from the server into an
HTML
i
page. The rendering engine constructs the
DOM
i
tree and renders and paints the construction and so on.
Naturally, all this activity takes some time before the user can interact with the page.
To cut down all this rendering time on the client, developers often render the
UI
i
on the server, generate
HTML
i
there and directly send the
HTML
i
page to the
UI
i
This technique is known as
server-side rendering
i
. It ensures faster rendering of the
UI
i
, averting the
UI
i
loading time in the browser window because the page is already created and the browser doesn’t have to do much assembling and rendering work.
Here are some use cases for both approaches of rendering the
UI
i
—on the
client
i
and the
server
i
Use cases for server-side & client-side rendering
b
The server-side rendering approach is perfect for delivering static content, such as
WordPress
i
blogs. It’s also good for
SEO
i
because the crawlers can easily read the generated content.
However, modern websites are highly dependent on
AJAX
i
. On such websites, content for a particular module or a page section has to be fetched and rendered on the fly. In this use case, the
server-side rendering
i
doesn’t help much.
If we render the
UI
i
on the server for
AJAX-based
i
websites, for every
AJAX
i
request, the approach will generate the entire page on the server as opposed to just sending the updated content to the client in response.
This process will prove to be resource-intensive and would consume unnecessary bandwidth, failing to provide a smooth user experience.
Also, once the number of concurrent users on the website goes up,
server-side rendering
i
will exert an unnecessary load on the server.
Moreover, we can leverage a hybrid approach to get the best of both worlds. We can use
server-side rendering
i
for the static content of our website and
client-side rendering
i
for dynamic content.
